Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 11:36AM kjbrown92 wrote: My doctor (GP) said that they knew it was a cyst if it was filled with fluid, and cysts cannot "turn into" breast cancer. So it's possible that they just identified it as a cyst. Though if you have a gut feeling, it's always best to get a second opinion.
Posts.Title: Should I get a second opinion txlouise keepthefaith

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 09:42AM kjbrown92 wrote: I had almost the same biopsy results. Then they did a wire removal (go in, they had put a titanium clip at the site during the biopsy, they locate it through xray or something like that, then stick a wire in it, then they put you under and remove the area). For me they found atypical cells also in it, but nothing else. I felt the same way. I felt like every time they said something, I was waiting for the "but..." to come. But... it didn't. Try not to worry.
Posts.Title: Radial Scar-Scared AGAIN Amykd Amykd

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 02:31PM kjbrown92 wrote: This is the decision making process I'm going through right now. Did they say anything about how fast moving your lumps were and what it meant? I had a clear mammogram last October, and the lump they just removed was 4cmx4.5cm (I found it in May). To me, that sounds fast growing. It was ADH. And I have a family history (mother with premenopausal breast cancer, paternal grandmother with postmenopausal breast cancer; and I have no sisters or aunts at all) as well. My BS suggested Tamoxifen and close monitoring, but I feel like you, get them off me before they kill me. I was thinking nipple sparing with implants, but now that you've spouted off these other acronyms, I guess I have to look into it. I'm supposed to be seeing an oncologist and a plastic surgeon at the beginning of September, then back to see the breast surgeon again. I'll be following your decisions, if you care to post them....
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperlasia and double mastectomy susskins CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2010 08:49PM kjbrown92 wrote: I think I am even more convinced now that the prophylactic bilateral I got a month ago was the right thing to do with the track record here. I've been to numerous doctors over the last 10 years (I'm 42). Chronic pain. The rheumatologist said I had all the symptoms of fibromyalgia but I didn't have it but she'd put me on the meds for it, but it didn't help at all. Turned out a lot of my muscle spasms were actually from food intolerances. Yet I still had chronic nerve pain. Finally found a good osteopath. I had low Vitamin D and I was just diagnosed 2 months ago with low thyroid, even though I've had symptoms for 4 years, which my regular doctor had poo-poo'd. I've been on a lot of anti-inflammatories (Pure Encapsulations makes a good one), and Magnesium is good for relaxing the muscles. I tried Tamoxifen and I could barely walk because of the hip pain. And with my 70% risk factor, I decided to go prophylactic. And now seeing all these theories tied together" low thyroid, chronic pain, inflammation, and low vitamin D (and after 3 years of supplementation, they still haven't gotten me to the 50 target), I'm glad I didn't wait.
Posts.Title: anyone out there with auto-immune/chronic pain issues before dx? jessamine SuzyBlue

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 09:52PM kjbrown92 wrote: One of the theories of cancer is that it's chronic inflammation that causes it. Have any of you researched gluten? Just curious because the rheumatologist thought I had fibro, and when I went off dairy, gluten, soy and corn (the top 4 food intolerances, and the ones that my kids had) my never-ending back spasms went away, and my thumb pain and my knee pain. Gluten is a problem with many auto immune diseases (celiac, RA, IBS, hashimoto's/grave's thyroid, and probably others) and it's inflammatory.  Not sure where you all live, but you might want to get checked for Lyme Disease as well (from a good lab like Igenex) because it can have many of the same symptoms.  And magnesium glycinate can help with muscle spasms (many people are low and don't know it; I had a blood test, but you're usually really low if it shows up on a blood test).  Just some things to think about.
Posts.Title: anyone out there with auto-immune/chronic pain issues before dx? jessamine SuzyBlue
